prompt.preamble:
We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences.
In this experiment, we'll be capturing your moral intuitions about the act of stealing a loaf of bread, and whether there are certain cases where stealing may be morally permissible.
prompt.task_description: your belief of when it is moral to steal a loaf of bread
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of moral situations, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your moral preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following situations are morally permissible or not: "yes" if they are, "no" if they aren't.

conversation_history.message: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are starving and the only bread available belongs to another poor person who is also hungry?

I think it really depends on how hungry that person is. In a vacuum where that person is just as starving as I am, then no, it isn't ethical to steal it. Obviously we should come to some kind of agreement

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you're not starving, but you need to feed it to a malnourished stray animal that's about to die, when the bread belongs to a well-off person who won't notice its absence?

Yes, in this case it is ethical. Here I think one can apply a simple utilitarian framework and realize that the well-off person won't be any worse off, and the animal will be strictly better off (ignoring future ramifications of the bread)

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you're not personally in need, but you intend to give it to a starving person, knowing that the bread was stolen from a small bakery struggling to stay afloat during a financial crisis?

It depends on how struggling the small bakery is. Again, I think we can apply a utilitarian framework and calculate the net utility from such a scenario. My intuition tells me this small bakery will be mostly fine, wile the starving person probably needs the bread more.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are wealthy but believe in the principle of freeganism, reducing waste by consuming discarded food, where the bread is about to be thrown away by a large supermarket chain?
Of course it is ethical. Given my previous responses, my answer here should be pretty obvious.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you're not starving, but you need to feed it to a group of homeless individuals, when the bread belongs to a charitable organization that's running a food drive for the same group of homeless individuals - but you believe they are inefficient and won't distribute the food on time?

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn under what conditions the user would believe it is or is not ethical to steal a loaf of bread.

Come up with a potential edge case to learn as much information as you can about what their desired behavior should be under different circumstances.
Make sure the edge case addresses different aspects of the system than the edge cases that have already been considered.

An example edge case is: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are starving to death and the bread would otherwise go to waste?

Current cases:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative edge case that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Generate the edge case in the following format, and nothing else: "Situation: [edge case]"
